TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . At the material time he was the Head of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL police officers ( NORP , GPE , GPE and GPE ) arrested CARDINAL persons suspected of offences related to the parliamentary elections ; CARDINAL of them was also suspected of being the leader of a criminal gang . Later the suspects were released from detention and complained to ORG of ill - treatment and illegal detention by the QUANTITY police officers . As a result of their complaint , a criminal investigation was initiated against the police officers on charges of , inter alia , ill - treatment and unlawful detention .

CARDINAL . In DATE the QUANTITY police officers wrote letters , which they signed jointly , to President PERSON , Prime Minister PERSON and the Deputy Speaker of ORG , Mr Mişin , seeking protection from prosecution . They set out their views on the criminal proceedings and complained that the actions of ORG were abusive . They asked for the legality of the criminal charges that had been brought against them to be verified . On DATE Mr Mişin forwarded the letter he had received , with an accompanying note , to ORG . The note was written on the official headed paper of the ORG and was not marked as being confidential . It stated as follows :
“ Dear PERSON ,

A question arises after reading this letter : is the Deputy Prosecutor General fighting crime or the police ? This issue is made even more pressing by the fact that the policemen concerned are from one of the best teams in ORG , whose activity is now being blocked as a result of the efforts of employees of ORG . I ask you personally to intervene in this case and solve it in strict compliance with the law . ”

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE PERSON visited the ORG where he discussed , inter alia , the problem of the undue pressure some public officials were putting on law - enforcement bodies in respect of pending criminal proceedings . The President made a call to fight corruption and asked law - enforcement officers to disregard any attempts by public officials to put them under pressure . The declarations of the President were made public by the media .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the criminal proceedings against the police officers were discontinued .
CARDINAL . DATE after PERSON made his call to fight corruption , the applicant sent to a newspaper , ORG , copies of CARDINAL letters ( “ the letters ” ) that had been received by ORG .

CARDINAL . The first was the note written by ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The second had been written by PERSON , a deputy minister in ORG , and was addressed to a deputy prosecutor general . It was written on the official headed paper of ORG and was not marked confidential . It stated , inter alia :

“ ... Police Major PERSON [ one of the CARDINAL officers , see paragraph CARDINAL above ] was convicted on CARDINAL DATE ... of offences under ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL [ illegal detention endangering life or health or causing physical suffering ] , CARDINAL § CARDINAL [ abuse of power accompanied by acts of violence , the use of a firearm or torture ] and CARDINAL § CARDINAL [ extracting a confession by acts of violence and insults ] of LAW and sentenced to a fine of CARDINAL NORP lei ( MONEY ) . Under section CARDINAL of LAW , he was exempted from paying the fine .
... on DATE , Major PERSON was reinstated in his post at ORG . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG published an article entitled “ PERSON intimidating prosecutors ” . The article stated , inter alia :

“ At DATE , during a meeting at FAC , the President called on law - enforcement institutions to cooperate in the fight against organised crime and corruption and asked them to ignore telephone calls from senior public officials concerning cases that were pending before them .

The President ’s initiative is not accidental . The phenomenon has become very widespread , especially during DATE , and has been the subject of debate in the mass media and in international organisations .

Recently the press reported on the case of the NORP Parliamentarian PERSON , who had attempted to influence a criminal investigation in respect of an old friend and high - ranking official at ORG who had been caught red - handed . However , no legal action was taken . ...

Also , the press reported that ORG had requested ORG to sack CARDINAL prosecutors , ORG , involved in the investigation into the disappearance of the Chief of ORG , GPE , apparently after they had found evidence implicating officials of ORG in wrongdoing .

The results of the internal investigation into the activities of these CARDINAL prosecutors are not yet known . However , sources at ORG have told this newspaper that even though ORG have not been found guilty , they have been asked to leave at the insistence of someone in authority .
Now , while the declarations of the President concerning trading in influence are still fresh on peoples’ minds , we reveal a new investigation concerning high - ranking officials .

The Deputy Speaker of ORG is attempting to protect CARDINAL police officers who are under criminal investigation . ORG affinity with policemen is not new , since his background is in the police force . Our sources stated that this is not the only case in which ORG has intervened on behalf of policemen in trouble with the law .
ORG initiated criminal proceedings against CARDINAL police officers ... after they had used force during the unlawful arrest of a group of people .

... [ The ] police officers assaulted the detainees by punching and kicking them ... Furthermore , it was found that one of the officers had made false statements in the police report on the arrest ... The QUANTITY police officers were also being investigated for forcibly extracting confessions ...
The investigation lasted for DATE . When it was almost over ... the police officers started to seek protection from those in authority .

On DATE the police officers wrote letters to President PERSON , Prime Minister PERSON and the Deputy Speaker of ORG , PERSON , asking them to intervene to end the investigation , which they said was unwarranted .

The first to react to their letter was the Deputy Speaker of ORG , PERSON . On DATE ... he sent the Prosecutor General a letter in which , in a commanding tone , he asked him personally to intervene in the case of the CARDINAL policemen . Even though he instructed ORG to get involved in this case ‘ in strict compliance with the law’ , the tone of the letter clearly shows that he was giving an order for the case to be examined very quickly .

As a result of the intervention of the ORG ’s most influential figures , ORG discontinued the criminal investigation against the policemen and ordered an internal investigation into the correctness of the decision to bring criminal proceedings against them ...

... Sources from ORG confirmed that officer ORG [ one of the CARDINAL policemen ] had [ previously ] been convicted by ORG , and ordered to pay a criminal fine of CARDINAL NORP lei . In accordance with LAW , he was exempted from paying the fine . Moreover , on DATE ... he was reinstated at ORG .

Without commenting on the judgment of ORG , we wish to make some remarks . PERSON was convicted on the basis of Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW of abuse of power , forcibly extracting confessions and unlawful detention . For these offences , LAW lays down sentences of one to DATE imprisonment . He was only given a fine .
Moreover , ORG reinstated him while he was still under investigation . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The newspaper article was accompanied by photographs of the letters signed by ORG and PERSON .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant was requested by ORG to explain how the CARDINAL letters had come to be published by the press .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote to ORG , admitting that he had sent the CARDINAL letters to the newspaper . He stated , inter alia :

“ My act was a reaction to the declarations made by the [ President ] concerning the fight against corruption and trading in influence . I did this because I was convinced that I was helping to fight the scourge of trading in influence ( trafic de influenţă ) , a phenomenon which has become increasingly common of late .

I believed and still believe that if each of us were to help uncover those who abuse their position in order to obstruct the proper administration of justice , the situation would change for the better .
Further , I consider that the letters I handed over to ORG were not secret . My intention was not to do a disservice to ORG , but on the contrary to create a positive image of it . ”
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date a prosecutor , ORG , who was suspected of having furnished the letters to the applicant , was dismissed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote a further letter to ORG , informing him that the letters had not been obtained through ORG He added :
“ If the manner in which I acted is considered a breach of the internal regulations , then I am the one who should bear responsibility .

I acted in compliance with ORG , LAW and LAW . I believed that the declarations of the [ President ] decrying acts of corruption and trading in influence were sincere . To my great regret , I note that ORG has elevated a letter from a public official ( which in my opinion is a clear example of direct political involvement in the administration of justice ) to the status of ORG secret . This fact , coupled with ORG dismissal , concerns me and causes me seriously to doubt that the rule of law and human rights are respected in GPE . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was dismissed . The letter of dismissal stated , inter alia , that the letters disclosed by the applicant to the newspaper were secret and that he had failed to consult the heads of other departments of ORG before handing them over , in breach of CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action against ORG seeking reinstatement . He argued , inter alia , that the letters he had disclosed to the newspaper were not classified as secret in accordance with the law ; that he was not obliged to consult the heads of other departments before contacting the press ; that he had given the letters to the newspaper at the newspaper ’s request ; and that his dismissal constituted a breach of his right to freedom of expression .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action . It stated , inter alia , that the applicant had breached his obligations under paragraph CARDINAL of LAW by not consulting other departmental heads and under paragraph CARDINAL of the Regulations by disclosing secret documents .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed . He relied on the same arguments as in his initial court action . He also argued that the disclosure of the letters to the newspaper had not in any way prejudiced his employer .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal on the same grounds as ORG . Referring to the applicant ’s submissions concerning freedom of expression , ORG stated that obtaining information through the abuse of one ’s position was not part of freedom of expression ( dreptul la exprimare nu presupune dobândirea informaţiei abuziv , folosind atribuţiile PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . Neither ORG nor the Deputy Speaker of ORG , Mr Mişin , appear to have contested the authenticity of the letters published in ORG or the truthfulness of the information contained in the article of DATE or to have taken any further action .

CARDINAL . Since ORG did not react in the manner ORG had anticipated after the publication of the article on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the latter initiated court proceedings for an order requiring ORG to initiate a criminal investigation into ORG alleged interference in an ongoing criminal investigation . The newspaper argued , inter alia , that , under LAW , newspaper articles and letters published in newspapers could serve as a basis for the institution of criminal proceedings and that ORG was under a duty to order an investigation .

CARDINAL . The newspaper ’s action was dismissed by ORG on DATE and by ORG on DATE . The courts found , inter alia , that the newspaper did not have legal standing to lodge a complaint and that , in any event , the article of DATE was merely a newspaper article expressing a personal point of view , not an official request to initiate a criminal investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG published a follow - up to its article of DATE entitled “ ORG launches crackdown on prosecutors ” . The piece described the events that had followed the publication of the first article and stated that ORG had been infuriated by the article and had ordered ORG to identify and punish those responsible for disclosing his note to the press . ORG had acquiesced and declared war on subordinates who refused to tolerate political intervention in the workings of the criminal - justice system . The article stated that the actions of ORG were in line with the general trend that had been observed in DATE of replacing people with considerable professional experience who were not prepared to comply with the rules instituted by the new government with people from dubious backgrounds . It claimed that sources from ORG had told the newspaper that ORG had received systematic indications from ORG and the advisers to the President concerning who should be employed or dismissed . In DATE , CARDINAL experienced prosecutors had been dismissed from ORG .

The article also gave an account of the applicant ’s dismissal as a result of pressure from ORG , and stated that sources at ORG had told the newspaper that the ORG had received CARDINAL of letters from ORG and PERSON ( another high - ranking public official ) in connection with ongoing criminal investigations .

According to the newspaper ’s sources , CARDINAL prosecutors had been dismissed at the insistence of ORG because they had discovered incriminating material against him during an investigation into the disappearance of an important businessman , PERSON After their dismissal that criminal investigation had been brought to an end .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Labour Code provided at the material time that employees of the central public authorities could be dismissed for a serious breach of their professional duties .

CARDINAL [ The Head of the Press Department ] is responsible for the quality of the published materials , the veracity of the information received and supplied , and for preserving confidentiality in accordance with the legislation of GPE . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure provided that , at the investigation stage , materials from a criminal file could not be disclosed except with the authorisation of the person in charge of the investigation .

CARDINAL . The relevant provision of ORG LAW of DATE reads :
“ Preamble
The member ORG , the other GPE and ORG , signatories hereto ,

Emphasising that corruption represents a major threat to the rule of law , democracy and human rights , fairness and social justice , hinders economic development and endangers the proper and fair functioning of market economies ;
Recognising the adverse financial consequences of corruption to individuals , companies and GPE , as well as international institutions ;
Have agreed as follows :

Each ORG shall provide in its internal law for appropriate protection against any unjustified sanction for employees who have reasonable grounds to suspect corruption and who report in good faith their suspicion to responsible persons or authorities . ”
ORG to this convention states with regard to LAW

“ CARDINAL . This Article deals with the need for each ORG to take the necessary measures to protect employees , who report in good faith and on the basis of reasonable grounds their suspicions on corrupt practices or behaviours , from being victimised in any way .

CARDINAL . As regards the necessary measures to protect employees provided for by LAW , the legislation of Parties could , for instance , provide that employers be required to pay compensation to employees who are victims of unjustified sanctions .

DATE . In practice corruption cases are difficult to detect and investigate and employees or colleagues ( whether public or private ) of the persons involved are often the first persons who find out or suspect that something is wrong .

CARDINAL . The ‘ appropriate protection against any unjustified sanction’ implies that , on the basis of [ the ] Convention , any sanction against employees based on the ground that they had reported an act of corruption to persons or authorities responsible for receiving such reports , will not be justified . Reporting should not be considered as a breach of the duty of confidentiality . Examples of unjustified sanctions may be a dismissal or demotion of these persons or otherwise acting in a way which limits progress in their career .
CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Therefore the appropriate protection which Parties are required to take should encourage employees to report their suspicions to the responsible person or authority . Indeed , in many cases , persons who have information of corruption activities do not report them mainly because of fear of the possible negative consequences .

CARDINAL . As far as employees are concerned , this protection provided covers only the cases where they have reasonable ground to report their suspicion and report them in good faith . In other words , it applies only to genuine cases and not to malicious ones . ”
This convention was signed by GPE on DATE and came into force in respect of GPE on DATE .
